data.meta_description: In Vilhelmina, the summers are cool, wet, and mostly cloudy and the winters are long, freezing, snowy, and overcast. Over the course of the year, the temperature typically varies from 7Â°F to 66Â°F and is rarely below -15Â°F or above 76Â°F.
data.text:
Climate and Average Weather Year Round in Vilhelmina Sweden

In Vilhelmina, the summers are cool, wet, and mostly cloudy and the winters are long, freezing, snowy, and overcast. Over the course of the year, the temperature typically varies from 7Â°F to 66Â°F and is rarely below -15Â°F or above 76Â°F.

Based on the tourism score, the best time of year to visit Vilhelmina for warm-weather activities is from early July to early August.

Climate in Vilhelmina

freezingvery coldcoldcoolcoolcoldvery coldfreezingJanFebMarAprMayJunJulAugSepOctNovDecNowNow47%47%21%21%overcastclearprecipitation: 3.9 inprecipitation: 3.9 in1.0 in1.0 inmuggy: 0%muggy: 0%0%0%drydrytourism score: 4.9tourism score: 4.90.00.0

Average Temperature in Vilhelmina

The warm season lasts for 3.1 months, from May 29 to August 31, with an average daily high temperature above 57Â°F. The hottest month of the year in Vilhelmina is July, with an average high of 65Â°F and low of 48Â°F.

The cold season lasts for 4.0 months, from November 13 to March 12, with an average daily high temperature below 29Â°F. The coldest month of the year in Vilhelmina is January, with an average low of 7Â°F and high of 21Â°F.

Clouds

In Vilhelmina, the average percentage of the sky covered by clouds experiences significant seasonal variation over the course of the year.

The clearer part of the year in Vilhelmina begins around April 17 and lasts for 4.6 months, ending around September 5.

The clearest month of the year in Vilhelmina is June, during which on average the sky is clear, mostly clear, or partly cloudy 46% of the time.

The cloudier part of the year begins around September 5 and lasts for 7.4 months, ending around April 17.

The cloudiest month of the year in Vilhelmina is January, during which on average the sky is overcast or mostly cloudy 78% of the time.

Precipitation

A wet day is one with at least 0.04 inches of liquid or liquid-equivalent precipitation. The chance of wet days in Vilhelmina varies throughout the year.

The wetter season lasts 4.6 months, from May 15 to October 4, with a greater than 30% chance of a given day being a wet day. The month with the most wet days in Vilhelmina is July, with an average of 12.5 days with at least 0.04 inches of precipitation.

The drier season lasts 7.4 months, from October 4 to May 15. The month with the fewest wet days in Vilhelmina is February, with an average of 6.0 days with at least 0.04 inches of precipitation.

Among wet days, we distinguish between those that experience rain alone, snow alone, or a mixture of the two. Based on this categorization, the most common form of precipitation in Vilhelmina changes throughout the year.

Rain alone is the most common for 7.1 months, from April 5 to November 8. The month with the most days of rain alone in Vilhelmina is July, with an average of 12.5 days.

Snow alone is the most common for 4.9 months, from November 8 to April 5. The month with the most days of snow alone in Vilhelmina is January, with an average of 6.9 days.

Daily Chance of Precipitation in Vilhelmina

Rainfall

To show variation within the months and not just the monthly totals, we show the rainfall accumulated over a sliding 31-day period centered around each day of the year. Vilhelmina experiences significant seasonal variation in monthly rainfall.

The rainy period of the year lasts for 7.8 months, from April 1 to November 25, with a sliding 31-day rainfall of at least 0.5 inches. The month with the most rain in Vilhelmina is July, with an average rainfall of 3.9 inches.

The rainless period of the year lasts for 4.2 months, from November 25 to April 1. The month with the least rain in Vilhelmina is January, with an average rainfall of 0.1 inches.

Average Monthly Rainfall in Vilhelmina

Snowfall

As with rainfall, we consider the snowfall accumulated over a sliding 31-day period centered around each day of the year. Vilhelmina experiences extreme seasonal variation in monthly snowfall.

The snowy period of the year lasts for 7.5 months, from September 28 to May 10, with a sliding 31-day snowfall of at least 1.0 inches. The month with the most snow in Vilhelmina is January, with an average snowfall of 11.8 inches.

The snowless period of the year lasts for 4.6 months, from May 10 to September 28. The least snow falls around July 27, with an average total accumulation of 0.0 inches.

Sun

The length of the day in Vilhelmina varies extremely over the course of the year. In 2024, the shortest day is December 21, with 3 hours, 50 minutes of daylight; the longest day is June 20, with 21 hours, 36 minutes of daylight.

Hours of Daylight and Twilight in Vilhelmina

The earliest sunrise is at 2:07 AM on June 20, and the latest sunrise is 7 hours, 50 minutes later at 9:57 AM on December 24. The earliest sunset is at 1:45 PM on December 18, and the latest sunset is 9 hours, 58 minutes later at 11:43 PM on June 21.

Daylight saving time (DST) is observed in Vilhelmina during 2024, starting in the spring on March 31, lasting 6.9 months, and ending in the fall on October 27.

Moon

The figure below presents a compact representation of key lunar data for 2024. The horizontal axis is the day, the vertical axis is the hour of the day, and the colored areas indicate when the moon is above the horizon. The vertical gray bars (new Moons) and blue bars (full Moons) indicate key Moon phases.

Humidity

We base the humidity comfort level on the dew point, as it determines whether perspiration will evaporate from the skin, thereby cooling the body. Lower dew points feel drier and higher dew points feel more humid. Unlike temperature, which typically varies significantly between night and day, dew point tends to change more slowly, so while the temperature may drop at night, a muggy day is typically followed by a muggy night.

The perceived humidity level in Vilhelmina, as measured by the percentage of time in which the humidity comfort level is muggy, oppressive, or miserable, does not vary significantly over the course of the year, remaining a virtually constant 0% throughout.

Humidity Comfort Levels in Vilhelmina

Wind

This section discusses the wide-area hourly average wind vector (speed and direction) at 10 meters above the ground. The wind experienced at any given location is highly dependent on local topography and other factors, and instantaneous wind speed and direction vary more widely than hourly averages.

The average hourly wind speed in Vilhelmina experiences mild seasonal variation over the course of the year.

The windier part of the year lasts for 7.0 months, from November 7 to June 7, with average wind speeds of more than 4.7 miles per hour. The windiest month of the year in Vilhelmina is January, with an average hourly wind speed of 5.3 miles per hour.

The calmer time of year lasts for 5.0 months, from June 7 to November 7. The calmest month of the year in Vilhelmina is August, with an average hourly wind speed of 4.2 miles per hour.

Average Wind Speed in Vilhelmina

Average Wind Speed in VilhelminawindywindyJanFebMarAprMayJunJulAugSepOctNovDec0 mph0 mph1 mph1 mph2 mph2 mph3 mph3 mph4 mph4 mph5 mph5 mph6 mph6 mph7 mph7 mph8 mph8 mphJan 235.4 mphJan 235.4 mphAug 74.1 mphAug 74.1 mphNov 74.7 mphNov 74.7 mphJun 74.7 mphJun 74.7 mphNowNow

The predominant average hourly wind direction in Vilhelmina varies throughout the year.

The wind is most often from the south for 3.3 weeks, from February 26 to March 20; for 3.0 months, from July 18 to October 19; and for 3.0 days, from November 3 to November 6, with a peak percentage of 37% on September 24. The wind is most often from the west for 3.9 months, from March 20 to July 18; for 2.1 weeks, from October 19 to November 3; and for 3.7 months, from November 6 to February 26, with a peak percentage of 35% on October 24.

Best Time of Year to Visit

To characterize how pleasant the weather is in Vilhelmina throughout the year, we compute two travel scores.

The tourism score favors clear, rainless days with perceived temperatures between 65Â°F and 80Â°F. Based on this score, the best time of year to visit Vilhelmina for general outdoor tourist activities is from early July to early August, with a peak score in the third week of July.

Tourism Score in Vilhelmina

Tourism Score in VilhelminaJanFebMarAprMayJunJulAugSepOctNovDec002244668810104.94.90.00.0NowNowcloudscloudsprecipitationprecipitationtourism score

The beach/pool score favors clear, rainless days with perceived temperatures between 75Â°F and 90Â°F. Based on this score, the best time of year to visit Vilhelmina for hot-weather activities is from mid to late July, with a peak score in the third week of July.

Beach/Pool Score in Vilhelmina

Beach/Pool Score in VilhelminaJanFebMarAprMayJunJulAugSepOctNovDec002244668810101.21.20.00.0NowNowcloudscloudsprecipitationprecipitation

Methodology

For each hour between 8:00 AM and 9:00 PM of each day in the analysis period (1980 to 2016), independent scores are computed for perceived temperature, cloud cover, and total precipitation. Those scores are combined into a single hourly composite score, which is then aggregated into days, averaged over all the years in the analysis period, and smoothed.

Our cloud cover score is 10 for fully clear skies, falling linearly to 9 for mostly clear skies, and to 1 for fully overcast skies.

Our precipitation score, which is based on the three-hour precipitation centered on the hour in question, is 10 for no precipitation, falling linearly to 9 for trace precipitation, and to 0 for 0.04 inches of precipitation or more.

Our tourism temperature score is 0 for perceived temperatures below 50Â°F, rising linearly to 9 for 65Â°F, to 10 for 75Â°F, falling linearly to 9 for 80Â°F, and to 1 for 90Â°F or hotter.

Our beach/pool temperature score is 0 for perceived temperatures below 65Â°F, rising linearly to 9 for 75Â°F, to 10 for 82Â°F, falling linearly to 9 for 90Â°F, and to 1 for 100Â°F or hotter.

Growing Season

Definitions of the growing season vary throughout the world, but for the purposes of this report, we define it as the longest continuous period of non-freezing temperatures (≥ 32Â°F) in the year (the calendar year in the Northern Hemisphere, or from July 1 until June 30 in the Southern Hemisphere).

The growing season in Vilhelmina typically lasts for 3.6 months (110 days), from around May 22 to around September 9, rarely starting before May 5 or after June 9, and rarely ending before August 21 or after September 29.

Time Spent in Various Temperature Bands and the Growing Season in Vilhelmina

frigid 15Â°F freezing 32Â°F very cold 45Â°F cold 55Â°F cool 65Â°F comfortable 75Â°F warm 85Â°F hot 95Â°F sweltering

Growing degree days are a measure of yearly heat accumulation used to predict plant and animal development, and defined as the integral of warmth above a base temperature, discarding any excess above a maximum temperature. In this report, we use a base of 50Â°F and a cap of 86Â°F.

Based on growing degree days alone, the first spring blooms in Vilhelmina should appear around June 7, only rarely appearing before May 24 or after June 26.

Solar Energy

This section discusses the total daily incident shortwave solar energy reaching the surface of the ground over a wide area, taking full account of seasonal variations in the length of the day, the elevation of the Sun above the horizon, and absorption by clouds and other atmospheric constituents. Shortwave radiation includes visible light and ultraviolet radiation.

The average daily incident shortwave solar energy experiences extreme seasonal variation over the course of the year.

The brighter period of the year lasts for 2.8 months, from May 10 to August 3, with an average daily incident shortwave energy per square meter above 4.6 kWh. The brightest month of the year in Vilhelmina is June, with an average of 5.6 kWh.

The darker period of the year lasts for 4.9 months, from October 5 to March 1, with an average daily incident shortwave energy per square meter below 1.2 kWh. The darkest month of the year in Vilhelmina is December, with an average of 0.0 kWh.

Average Daily Incident Shortwave Solar Energy in Vilhelmina

Topography

For the purposes of this report, the geographical coordinates of Vilhelmina are 64.624 deg latitude, 16.656 deg longitude, and 1,201 ft elevation.

The topography within 2 miles of Vilhelmina contains only modest variations in elevation, with a maximum elevation change of 472 feet and an average elevation above sea level of 1,168 feet. Within 10 miles contains only modest variations in elevation (909 feet). Within 50 miles contains very significant variations in elevation (4,068 feet).

The area within 2 miles of Vilhelmina is covered by trees (45%), water (35%), and artificial surfaces (12%), within 10 miles by trees (71%) and herbaceous vegetation (16%), and within 50 miles by trees (75%) and herbaceous vegetation (14%).

Data Sources

This report illustrates the typical weather in Vilhelmina, based on a statistical analysis of historical hourly weather reports and model reconstructions from January 1, 1980 to December 31, 2016.

Temperature and Dew Point

There are 4 weather stations near enough to contribute to our estimation of the temperature and dew point in Vilhelmina.

For each station, the records are corrected for the elevation difference between that station and Vilhelmina according to the International Standard Atmosphere , and by the relative change present in the MERRA-2 satellite-era reanalysis between the two locations.

The estimated value at Vilhelmina is computed as the weighted average of the individual contributions from each station, with weights proportional to the inverse of the distance between Vilhelmina and a given station.

The stations contributing to this reconstruction are:

Storuman Airport (ESPD, 59%, 40 mi, northeast, -272 ft elevation change)

Hemavan Airport (ESUT, 17%, 94 mi, northwest, 302 ft elevation change)

HÃ¶ga Kusten Airport (ESNK, 12%, 114 mi, south, -1,168 ft elevation change)

Ã re Ãstersund Airport (ESNZ, 12%, 118 mi, southwest, 33 ft elevation change)

To get a sense of how much these sources agree with each other, you can view a comparison of Vilhelmina and the stations that contribute to our estimates of its temperature history and climate. Please note that each source's contribution is adjusted for elevation and the relative change present in the MERRA-2 data.

Other Data

All data relating to the Sun's position (e.g., sunrise and sunset) are computed using astronomical formulas from the book, Astronomical Algorithms 2nd Edition , by Jean Meeus.

All other weather data, including cloud cover, precipitation, wind speed and direction, and solar flux, come from NASA's MERRA-2 Modern-Era Retrospective Analysis . This reanalysis combines a variety of wide-area measurements in a state-of-the-art global meteorological model to reconstruct the hourly history of weather throughout the world on a 50-kilometer grid.

Land Use data comes from the Global Land Cover SHARE database , published by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations.

Elevation data comes from the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) , published by NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

Names, locations, and time zones of places and some airports come from the GeoNames Geographical Database .

Time zones for airports and weather stations are provided by AskGeo.com .

Maps are © OpenStreetMap contributors.

Disclaimer

The information on this site is provided as is, without any assurances as to its accuracy or suitability for any purpose. Weather data is prone to errors, outages, and other defects. We assume no responsibility for any decisions made on the basis of the content presented on this site.

We draw particular cautious attention to our reliance on the MERRA-2 model-based reconstructions for a number of important data series. While having the tremendous advantages of temporal and spatial completeness, these reconstructions: (1) are based on computer models that may have model-based errors, (2) are coarsely sampled on a 50 km grid and are therefore unable to reconstruct the local variations of many microclimates, and (3) have particular difficulty with the weather in some coastal areas, especially small islands.

We further caution that our travel scores are only as good as the data that underpin them, that weather conditions at any given location and time are unpredictable and variable, and that the definition of the scores reflects a particular set of preferences that may not agree with those of any particular reader.
